facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 372 of 1956 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 372 of 1956. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated January 18, 1956 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 43 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1956, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 43 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on October 26, 1960 by WANCHOO J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. October 26. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO J.-This is an appeal

facts.text: Respondent carries on trade of hulling rice, milling grains and extracting oil in village Nandganj within Gaon Sabha Barapur.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is carrying on the trade of hulling rice, milling grains and extracting oil in village Nandganj within the area of Gaon Sabha Barapur.

facts.text: Respondent obtained licences under United Provinces Rice and Dal Control Order, 1948 and Uttar Pradesh Pure Food Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained licences for the three trades under the United Provinces Rice and Dal Control Order, 1948, as also under the Uttar Pradesh Pure Food Act, 1950.

facts.text: Gaon Sabha imposed Rs. 8/- fee on each mill and respondent had been paying it.

anchor.surface_text: Further the Gaon Sabha of Rs. 8/- on each mill within its jurisdiction and the respondent had been paying that as well.

facts.text: In 1953 District Board Ghazipur enforced bye-laws for regulation of flour, rice and oil mills requiring licence fee of Rs. 20/- per year per mill.

anchor.surface_text: In 1953 the District Board, Ghazipur, in which district the village is situate, enforced bye-laws for the regulation and control of flour, rice and oil mills in the rural areas of the district under which a licence has to be obtained by such mills on payment of Rs. 20/- as licence-fee per year per mill.

facts.text: Respondent served with notice to take out licence and pay fee.

anchor.surface_text: When the respondent was served with a notice to take out a licence for each mill and to pay the licence-fee,

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 challenging legality of levy.

anchor.surface_text: he objected to the legality and validity of the levy and thereafter filed a writ petition in the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondent contended District Board divested of power after constitution of Gaon Sabha under U.P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: His contention in this connection was three-fold, namely- i After the constitution of Gaon Sabha Barapur under the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, No. XXVI of 1947, the District Board had been divested of its power and jurisdiction

facts.text: Respondent contended already paid licence fees under 1948 Control Order and 1950 Food Act.

anchor.surface_text: ii the respondent had paid the necessary licence-fees under the U.P. Rice and Dal Control Order, 1948 and the U. P. Pure Food Act, 1950 and could not be asked to pay the licence-fees over again

facts.text: Respondent contended levy too high and for augmenting revenues.

anchor.surface_text: iii in any case the levy was too high and not in proportion to the actual and probable expenses which the District Board would have to incur in controlling or regulating trade and was meant to augment the general revenues

facts.text: Single Judge of High Court dismissed writ petition by reasoned judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was heard by a learned Single Judge of the High Court who appears to have dismissed it in limine by a reasoned judgment negativing all the three contentions raised by the respondent.

facts.text: Appeal Court allowed the appeal holding District Board lost power under s.174 due to s.111 Panchayat Raj Act.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then went in appeal and the Appeal Court allowed the appeal holding that in view of s. 111 of the Panchayat Raj Act, the District Board had lost its power to make bye-laws for the regulation and control of trade under s. 174 of the District Boards Act.

facts.text: Appeal Court held levy not a fee but disproportionate to expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The Appeal Court was further of the view that the levy was not out of proportion to the expenses to be incurred by the District Board in the matter of regulation and control and was not a tax.

facts.text: Appeal Court did not decide the third contention.

anchor.surface_text: It did not decide the third point raised on behalf of the respondent.

facts.text: District Board applied for and obtained certificate to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The District Board then applied for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us.

facts.text: It is not in dispute that District Board has power under relevant provisions to frame bye-laws for hulling rice, milling grains, extracting oil.

anchor.surface_text: It is not in dispute that the District Board has power under these provisions to frame bye-laws for regulation of these trades, namely, hulling rice, milling grains and extracting oil.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside Appeal Court order, dismissed writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the appeal is allowed, the order of the Appeal Court set aside and the writ petition dismissed.

facts.text: Village Nandganj is in district Ghazipur.

anchor.surface_text: District Board, Ghazipur, in which district the village is situate,

under Art. 226 of the Constitution. His contention in this connection was three-fold, namely- i After the constitution of Gaon Sabha Barapur under the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, No. XXVI of 1947, the District Board had been divested of its power and jurisdiction in the matter of regulation and control of trade under the relevant provisions of the U. P. District Boards Act, No. X of 1922 ii the respondent had paid the necessary licence-fees under the U.P. Rice and Dal Control Order, 1948 and the U. P. Pure Food Act, 1950 and could not be asked to pay the licence-fees over again under the District Boards Act and iii in any case the levy was too high and not in proportion to the actual and probable expenses which the District Board would have to incur in controlling or regulating trade and was meant to augment the general revenues of the District Board.

in view of s. 111 of the Panchayat Raj Act, the District Board had lost its power to make bye-laws for the regulation and control of trade under s. 174 of the District Boards Act. The Appeal Court was further of the view that the levy was not out of proportion to the expenses to be incurred by the District Board in the matter of regulation and control and was not a tax. It did not decide the third point raised on behalf of the respondent. The District Board then applied for a certificate to appeal to this Court, which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us.

issues.text: Whether, after the constitution of Gaon Sabha Barapur under the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, No. XXVI of 1947, the District Board had been divested of its power and jurisdiction in the matter of regulation and control of trade under the relevant provisions of the U. P. District Boards Act, No. X of 1922?

anchor.surface_text: After the constitution of Gaon Sabha Barapur under the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, No. XXVI of 1947, the District Board had been divested of its power and jurisdiction in the matter of regulation and control of trade under the relevant provisions of the U. P. District Boards Act, No. X of 1922

issues.text: The main question which falls for consideration in this appeal is whether the view of the Appeal Court that the District Board has lost its power to make bye-laws under s. 174 of the District Boards Act for regulation and control of trade in view of s. 111 of the Panchayat Raj Act, is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The main question which falls for consideration in this appeal is whether the view of the Appeal Court that the District Board has lost its power to make bye-laws under s. 174 of the District Boards Act for regulation and control of trade in view of s. 111 of the Panchayat Raj Act, is correct.

issues.text: Whether the Panchayat Raj Act contains any provision by which the Gaon Sabha or the Gaon Panchayat has been given the power to regulate or control trade?

anchor.surface_text: The writ petition was heard by a learned Single Judge of the High Court who appears to have dismissed it in limine by a reasoned judgment negativing all the three contentions raised by the respondent.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n is s. 37 d  by which a Gaon Sabha has been given the power to impose a tax on trades, callings and professions, number exceeding such rate as may be

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed on second point; first point reversed by Appeal Court but SC reverses back

holdings.text: the word sanitation as used in s. 15 of the Panchayat Raj Act is confined to its ordinary meaning in relation to conservancy and drainage and the like with reference to the necessity of avoiding dirt and disease and cannot be given such a wide meaning as to include control or regulation of trades, callings or practices.

anchor.surface_text: In the context therefore of both the District Boards Act and the Panchayat Raj Act, it seems to us that the word sanitation as used in s. 91 of the District Boards Act and s. 15 of the Panchayat Raj Act is confined to its ordinary meaning in relation to conservancy and drainage and the like with reference to the necessity of avoiding dirt and disease and cannot be given such a wide meaning as to include control or regulation of trades, callings or practices.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of both Acts uses 'sanitation' in narrow sense (e.g., separate clauses for water supply, manure disposal); wide meaning would render other provisions redundant.

holdings.text: The Panchayat Raj Act does not provide for control and regulation of trades, callings or practices like s. 91 q of the District Boards Act.

anchor.surface_text: It must therefore be held that the Panchayat Raj Act does not provide for control and regulation of trades, callings or practices like s. 91 q of the District Boards Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: ss.15 and 16 lack provision corresponding to District Boards Act s.91(q); sanitation interpreted narrowly; s.37(d) is for taxes not regulation.

holdings.text: The power to frame bye-laws under s. 111 is conditioned by the duties and functions imposed on a Gaon Panchayat under ss. 15 and 16 as well as other provisions of the Panchayat Raj Act.

anchor.surface_text: The power to frame bye-laws under s. 111 is, in our opinion, conditioned by the duties and functions imposed on a Gaon Panchayat under ss. 15 and 16 as well as other provisions of the Panchayat Raj Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.111 bye-laws must further administration under Act's duties; no duty for trade regulation, so no power.

holdings.text: as the Panchayat Raj Act does not provide for control or regulation of the nature mentioned in s. 91 q of the District Boards Act, there is no question of the power of the District Board under s. 174 to frame bye-laws and to prescribe fees in that behalf being taken away by s. 111 of the Panchayat Raj Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that as the Panchayat Raj Act does not provide for control or regulation of the nature mentioned in s. 91 q of the District Boards Act, there is no question of the power of the District Board under s. 174 to frame bye-laws and to prescribe fees in that behalf being taken away by s. 111 of the Panchayat Raj Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express repeal; no implied repeal as no inconsistency (Panchayat Act silent on trade regulation); District Board duties under s.91(q) unaffected.

holdings.text: the fees levied under the Control Order of 1948 which depends for its existence on the Essential Supplies Act and under the U. P. Pure Food Act are for different purposes of those Acts. The fee charged by the District Board is for regulation of obnoxious trades and the purpose of this regulation is different from the purpose for which fees are levied under the Essential Supplies Act and the Pure Food Act.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the learned Single Judge, the fees levied under the Control Order of 1948 which depends for its existence on the Essential Supplies Act and under the U. P. Pure Food Act are for different purposes of those Acts. The fee charged by the District Board

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different regulatory purposes: food control/purity vs obnoxious trade regulation; multiple fees permissible despite overlap.

holdings.text: s. 37 d by which a Gaon Sabha has been given the power to impose a tax on trades, callings and professions ... has nothing to do with the regulation of trades, callings and practices and levying of licence-fees in that behalf. What this provision refers to is what is provided in item 60 of List II of the Seventh Schedule and not fees properly so-called.

anchor.surface_text: The only other section to which our attention is drawn is s. 37 d by which a Gaon Sabha has been given the power to impose a tax on trades, callings and professions, not exceeding such rate as may be prescribed. This in our opinion has nothing to do with the regulation of trades, callings and practices and levying of licence-fees in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes regulatory licence fees from constitutional taxes on professions/trades.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the appeal is allowed, the order of the Appeal Court set aside and the writ petition dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed, order of the Appeal Court set aside, writ petition dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the context therefore of both the District Boards Act and the Panchayat Raj Act, it seems to us that the word sanitation as used in s. 91 of the District Boards Act and s. 15 of the Panchayat Raj Act is confined to its ordinary meaning in relation to conservancy and drainage and the like with reference to the necessity of avoiding dirt and disease and cannot be given such a wide meaning as to include control or regulation of trades, callings or practices.
In this view of the matter, the appeal is allowed, the order of the Appeal Court set aside and the writ petition dismissed.
